description.text: Latest version with currency symbols and a removable plug: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:693533

Christmas present! Birthday present! Other occasions! Print them out now, save your change, and give them to your children or grandchildren when the time comes. I travel back and forth to the UK so I needed a piggy bank to keep my pounds in too, and to be able to tell them apart. I've added currency symbols for dollars, pounds, and euros. All three are here. These are traditional style - break apart to get the coins (or spend a long time shaking them out). If you're careful about cutting it open (the responsibility is entirely yours), you may be able to superglue it back together. This prints in one piece. If you want this without the currency symbols, print the original at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105742

This is 100mm x 100mm on the base, 91mm high.  Print in one piece - make sure the base is stuck firmly flat on the bed before continuing on to the upper layers.  I used 1.75mm ABS at 205C on a 94C borosilicate glass bed with hairspray.

title: A Rostock max v2 mount for 2 geared extruders

description.text: This is a mount for two of Richrap's geared extruders which can be found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60531. This is useful if you're trying to get an E3d Cyclops print setup working as this will require the higher pressures you can get from a geared extruder. It works ok but if you have a long grub screw / bolt on the driven cog you may find that the hole is too small. I've included the sketchup file for you to modify. You will need the support that comes with the original Rostock mount and the two plastic nut holders from Alexstoff's dual ezstruder mount - found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364325.

title: Universal phone/webcam holder to stream the printing progress.

description.text:
Hello all,
this is an universal Camera/phone holder which can be mounted on your Aluminium rail. Update (Dec 25, 2015): re-created as Version 2, optimized some things. The point is I turned my old Android phone into an online webcam/video streaming device to monitor the printing progress. I won't describe all the details here, but these are the basics:
  • Stuff consists of 4 main pieces:
    a) M6 T Slot Nut (for 30x30mm ALU profile). If you have a 20x20mm ALU profile, download your M4 Slot Nut here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1061769
    b) mount.stl - to be mounted to the ALU profile
    c) leg.stl - default model is 150mm tall, should be suitable for most printers
    d) hook.stl - bottom and upper phone holders - print 2 pieces.
  • you need 4x M6 screws and 4x M6 nuts.
  • You need an old Android phone with IP Webcam package installed:
    https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.pas.webcam
  • Working local WiFi to be able to connect to the phone from your PC or tablet
    • I also attached an original OpenSCAD file which can generate all parts of this cam holder with any dimensions you like, except of the M6/M4 Slot Nut. (for M4 size, see link above. For M6 size, check here For other details or instructions, feel free to comment or send me a message.

Printer:

Rebel II. - customized

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: Support needed for the mount-v2.stl only.

description.text: Tsar Bomba (Russian: Царь-бомба; "Tsar-bomb") is the nickname for the AN602 hydrogen bomb, the most powerful nuclear weapon ever detonated. Its test on October 30, 1961, remains the most powerful man-made explosion in human history. It was also referred to as Kuz'kina Mat' (Russian: Кузькина мать, Kuzma's mother),[2] referring to Nikita Khrushchev's promise to show the United States a "Kuz'kina Mat'" at the 1960 United Nations General Assembly. Developed by the Soviet Union, the bomb had the yield of 50 megaton TNT (210 PJ). Only one bomb of this type was ever officially built and it was detonated in the Novaya Zemlya archipelago, at Sukhoy Nos.

comments.text:
Ever wondered how a trumpet can play so many notes with only three valves? You can play "natural notes" on a trumpet without valves.
These are multiples of the ground frequency (230Hz).

title: Kossel Mini top mounted spool tensioner magnetic

description.text:
I made a kossel mini from think3dprint3d and over the moon with it.... apart from the top mounted spool holder runs way too smoothly on a bearing. so the spools have a tendency to unravel, which at times have caused a loop to fall under the spool, tighten and lock up, causing the extruder to stop and the print to fail. This is a tensioner which places just enough tension on the spool to stop this but still allows the filament to run smoothly.
it also allows free movement but a constant tension if the spool is slightly misaligned or not quite circular Once it is set up there is micro adjustment on the pressure by moving slightly the small tensioner.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: the large plate is printed upside down to give a smooth as possible surface to allow the long tensioner to move freely. At 50mm/s this takes 1 hour 16 minutes for the complete plate to print

pictures to follow Bill of Materials
m3 x 20 socket cap screw x2
m3 x 8 socket cap screw x4
m3 nut x6
3mm dia x 3mm neodymium magnets x2 http://www.first4magnets.com/circular-disc-rod-magnets-c34/3mm-dia-x-3mm-thick-n42-neodymium-magnet-0-29kg-pull-p3328 ream all holes on the print with a 3mm sdrill bit
the long screws go through the posts and then attach to the top frame pic 1
then the plate is put over the screws pic2
add the long tensioner with a magnet in the small holepic3
add the short tensioner with magnet in the hole at the end (make sure it is opposing the other one)pic4
add knobs, make the long tensioner so it is free to rotate & make the short one tight pic5
add spool and adjust posts so there is a small air gap of 2-3 mm to adjust tension on the spool pic 6 attach posts to the frame with long screws through the posts. then the plate is put over the screws add the long tensioner with a magnet in the small hole add the short tensioner with magnet in the hole at the end (make sure it is opposing the other one) add knobs, make the long tensioner so it is free to rotate & make the short one tight add spool and adjust posts so there is a small air gap of 2-3 mm to adjust tension on the spool

theory I wanted to be able to place enough tension on the spool to stop it unraveling but not put too much tension in to restrict the movement of the filament. after trying numerous ideas with springs and elastic bands, i settled on two opposing magnets. the first one is being printed as i type so i will post final pictures tomorrow

Final version V4 Schoolboy error on the knobs, they are now made so the nuts drop in from the top of the knob. so you can tighten them up. it works perfectly
once the position of the posts is set up to allow a small gap between the magnets full pressure is applied when the two magnets are directly opposite each other. this can be adjusted by moving the small tensioner clockwise or ant clockwise

author: xSiNx

description.text: This is a simple case for the Logic Shrimp logic analyzer from Dangerous Prototypes: http://dangerousprototypes.com/docs/Logic_Shrimp_logic_analyzer

Case is designed to be cut out of 1/8" acrylic, although 3mm should work too even though I have not confirmed this. However I did successfully create a prototype out of 1/8" plywood without any changes.
On the top there are openings for ICSP, output and external. Most people will probably not need these so remove them before cutting the pieces. If using transparent acrylic the two holes over the status LEDs can also be removed.
The top was designed to accept PLP2-375 light pipes (492-1341-ND at Digi-Key) for the two indicator lights on the board, but I have not tried that yet.
If you're using opaque acrylic you might want to add etched text over the opening(s) to indicate channel #, ground etc.
The fasteners can be exchanged for 1" and 3/8" 4-40 bolts with corresponding nuts.

description.text:

Printed two clips to keep the drive in the case.  The fit with my pla filament print is a bit loose (red filament from printrbot) - probably prefer that to too snug to get out.
Hopefully the hard drive is cool enough to not melt the plastic.
I recommend sticking on some rubber feet so it doesn't slide around.

title: Wanhao i3 Auto Bed level System

description.text:
Wanhao i3 Printer Modification.
  • Uses two push button switches mounted
    • This is a work in progress and not fully tested.
    Due to the switch type and the existing firmware.
    A new firmware needs to be loaded into the printer that supports bed leveling and the z axis switch needs to change to normally closed. I used two switches from an arduino kit.
    I think it is similar to this one.
    https://www.adafruit.com/products/367 Tested with new firmware and it WORKS!!!
    I used the firmware from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/wanhao-printer-3d/pjWof2uIkNE/AjJ2oZicnF0J
    I flashed a boot loader to the printer by using an arduino uno as an ISP.
    After the boot loader was flashed I could then just upload the new printer code using a USB cable to the printer. I had to remove sd card support on line 904 of the pins.h
    In configuration.h : #define FEATURE_Z_PROBE true #define Z_PROBE_PIN 20 #define Z_PROBE_PULLUP true #define Z_PROBE_ON_HIGH true #define Z_PROBE_X1 20 #define Z_PROBE_Y1 20 #define Z_PROBE_X2 180 #define Z_PROBE_Y2 100 #define Z_PROBE_X3 20 #define Z_PROBE_Y3 180 #define ENDSTOP_Z_MIN_INVERTING false #define ALWAYS_CHECK_ENDSTOPS 0 https://youtu.be/2uBcsVxugy0
    https://youtu.be/RGHcs_r65LY

Wanhao i3

comments.author: MaleBuffy

comments.text:
The new switches are wired in series to the endstop switch input. The old endstop is removed.
This allows us to use one input to monitor the state of both switches. The input changes whenever one of the switches is opened.
This does require a firmware change since the state of the endstop switch is reversed.

Yes. In use and barely think about leveling anymore.

description.text:
This model I have designed myself - inspired by a similar "coins keeper vase" in Vienna contemporary art museum. The vase has a flat bottom and the surface is closed on the top to be printed with a "vase" mode.
When printed in ABS with 3 layers it is waterproof. Minimum supports are required for the first lowest layers and the flat bottom. No internal supports are needed to print the rest of the body. Notes: other variations of self-standing ball vases and coin keeper boxes are coming soon, keep tuned.

Focus- is a unique and intuitive organisational timer which aims to keep you focused for fixed intervals of time. Inspired by the Pomodoro technique Focus builds on the readily available egg timers, apps and stopwatches to create a streamlined intuive solution to keeping focus on a task at hand. The key to Focus's simplistic design is a dual material PLA (Hard) / TPE (Flex) composite lid which allows for a completely concealed push button. This is achieved by adding a M600 (change filament command) to your gcode at a height of 5mm. This can be done manually or with the help of ColorPrint by Prusa3D (http://www.prusa3d.com/drivers/) https://youtu.be/TL5tirKLWrw

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05, 0.1, 0.2

Infill:

45%

Notes: Print parts with the outside surfaces facing upwards.
This way any unsightly overhangs or support marks are hidden once assembled. Top:
If you have sufficient cooling you can print this part without supports.
After saving the .gcode file, add a M600 change filament command 5mm into the print either manually or by dragging it into ColorPrint by Prusa3D. Bottom:
I recommend support to allow the twist lock contacts to print without issues.

1. Standby Focus sits waiting for input to start a session. 2. Focus At the push of a button a 25min timer is started.
Remaining time is conveyed by a NeoPixel ring dropping an LED every 1m30s.
A vibrating motor provides tactile feedback to each button press and adds an audible cue when the 25 minutes is complete. If something comes to your mind during your 25min Focus, make a note of it. Its normal to have a small list of "distractions" so check on during your 5min rest. 3. Distractions After your 25min, a 5min timer is started which provides time to catch up on any distractions experienced within your Focus time.
Need more time? Hit Focus again to add an additional 5min you might need to complete a task Once the 5min is up Focus will return to standby and wait for you to start another session.

Printed Parts

  • Base
    PLA

  • Lid
    0mm - 5mm: PLA
    5mm + TPE / Ninjaflex / Filaflex
    • Electronics
  • Lillypad, Microduino, Digispark or other small Arduino compatible device.
  • NeoPixel Ring 16
  • Lithium Ion Battery
  • Push Button
  • Vibration Motor
  • Additional wires

1. Programming Download the "focus.ino" file.
Download the elapsedMillis & FastLED libraries. Once opened change the four pin numbers to the Arduino pins you intend to use. 2. Electronics To fit all of the components inside the Focus case you will need to solder each part without headers. Headers typically take up too much space in compact projects and don't work in this case.
It may be useful to solder the circuit together first and then change the code's four pin numbers in the "focus.ino" file before uploading to the Arduino.

title: makergear m2 adjustable bed corner clamp no pad REV E

description.text: this is another version of my adjustable bed corner clamp for the makergear m2. this has no support pad and is currently for the REV E machines and for people who have updated their spider with the 4 point leveling. all other m2 owners please use the original version which can be found here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602194 these corners adjust to your glass of mic6 removing any play so you no longer need any binder clips. print a set of 4 of these. the screws dont need to be tight. they should not apply pressure to the plate. they should only take play or movement out of the bed. the hole is for an m3 screw size. i suggest the hole is cleaned up with a drill bit and tapped to the correct thread or atleast drilled out so the screw can just make its own threads into the plastic. i suggest printing these in abs or epc at 100% infill.

These hooks will go on a HobbyKing S600 Quadcopter but can go on any other similarly configured drone. My measured distances are 59mm between rods and 24mm hole distance. This is not normal, so you would have to slightly adjust the openSCAD file I have provided if yours features the usual 60mm rod spacing and the 23mm hole distance.
You can also adjust the depth of the hooks to adapt for lighter or heavier batteries. Currently the STL has 12mm depth.
The upper shape is a parabola, contact me if you need help adjusting the parameters to smoothly hit the claw shape.
I will follow up with a battery tray that features slits for velcro straps and stops that prevent the battery from slipping out.
Here's the configurable battery tray: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1219149 The hooks will hold regular M3 hex nuts and the holes should accept M3 machine screws without drilling.

NEW VIDEO! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gCGmpHHC0Ag It's a 3D printed clock! WOOT! It consists of 12 number plates, 2 gears, and 1 mount. All units are inches. In the zip folder are two versions of the main drive gear and clock base (10" gear). The gear I sectioned into four pieces (print two of each) and a version of the drive gear that does not need supports. This should main clock base should fit on most hobby printers. I made everything so that it requires no support and fits within a 4x4" box.

You will need to purchase the clock shown in the photos from Walmart or any craft clock assembly should work.  I picked up the Mainstays clock because it was only $3.97 and I was unable to find the kit clock mechanism locally.
If you purchase the Mainstays clock all you need to do is remove the screws around the back perimeter of the clock.  Once removed you have access to the clock hands.  First remove the second hand, then the minute hand and finally the hour hand.  Only a gentle pull is needed.  Once removed you can pry the plastic tabs on the clock backing out to remove the clock mechanism.  I found a small amount of glue on mine which may make it a bit difficult.
While your parts are printing you will need to take apart the clock mechanism.  Make sure you remember how it goes back together.  You need to access the hour hand gear and shaft.  Remove the minute hand and second hand gears.  Place the hour hand gear back into the clock housing and use a fine hacksaw or Dremel tool to cut the shaft flush with the clock housing.  We need to cut it off because the hour hand obviously only rotates once every 12 hours.  We need to press the printed clock gear onto the minute hand shaft since it rotates once every hour hence the 12:1 gear ratio.  Reassemble the clock mechanism once complete.
Once you get all the 3D parts printed you will need to hot glue the clock mechanism into the clock mechanism mount and press the drive gear on the minute hand shaft.  You will also need to glue the numbers to the clock base and probably assemble the clock base pieces if you have a small 3d printing bed. (Less than 10x10 inches)

description.text:
***UPDATE 26DEC 2015: Replaced .scad file with version 1.7 that now has several additions. GoPro connector from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62800 was hacked in. Top and bottom bevel options are now available. The "scoop" bottom style is experimental for future use in the water jet drive propulsion system. ***UPDATE 25 DEC 2015: Replaced .scad file with version 1.4 that now includes fishing pole holder option. ***UPDATE 24 DEC 2015: Replaced .scad file with version 1.3. Some variable names have changed, more options available and improvements have been made. Goal: To create threaded scupper plugs for my Pelican Boost 100 kayak. Why? To keep my butt from getting wet and to potentially use the scupper holes as mount point for attachments like gopro camera mount, electric motor mount, fish rod or paddle holder, and etc. Status: This currently a work-in-progress, files maybe changed and/or added. This is my first attempt at using the thingiverse customizer. Using anything other than the low default detail may cause the customizer script to time-out. I recommend running this in openSCAD for final rendering at high detail before exporting to .stl and printing. Plugs that will work for the front scupper holes of my Pelican Boost 100 kayak. They can be recreated by using the following vars:
Scuppers_bolt__Pelican_B100_front_top.stl
plug_length = 32;
plug_detail = 360;
thread_detail = 8;
top_diameter = 26;
top_style = "bolt";
top_thread_length = 15;
top_thread_diameter = 22;
top_thread_pitch = 4;
bottom_diameter = 38;
bottom_style = "slot";
slot_size = 2; Scuppers_nut_Pelican_B100_front_bottom.stl
plug_length = 26;
plug_detail = 360;
thread_detail = 8;
top_diameter = 26;
top_style = "nut";
top_thread_length = 16;
top_thread_diameter = 22.5;
top_thread_pitch = 4;
bottom_diameter = 38;
bottom_style = "slot";
slot_size = 2; Note: I have found that it is best to add about .5 to the thread diameter of the bolt to create a matching nut. You may find that your printer / plastic / temperature may require an adjustment to this. The pole holder uses the nut above. It can be recreated with:
Pelican_front_pole_holder.stl
plug_length = 33;
plug_detail = 360;
thread_detail = 8;
top_diameter = 39;
top_style = "pole_holder";
bottom_diameter = 26;
bottom_style = "bolt";
bottom_thread_length = 15;
bottom_thread_diameter = 22;
bottom_thread_pitch = 4;
pole_holder_length = 115;
pole_holder_outer_diameter = 40;
pole_holder_inner_diameter = 28;
pole_holder_base_diameter = 80; Rear plugs that self tread in the rear holes of a Pelican Boost 100 kayak can be recreated with:
Pelican_rear_top_bolt.stl
plug_length = 32;
plug_detail = 360;
thread_detail = 8;
top_diameter = 23;
top_style = "bolt";
top_thread_length = 15;
top_thread_diameter = 22.5;
top_thread_pitch = 5;
bottom_diameter = 38;
bottom_style = "slot";
slot_size = 2;

Have you ever wanted to just have some basic things, but not wanted to lug things around like backpack. Well you can  now. This design is called the mini back pack. It includes an abacus for simple math calculations, a card holder for credit cards debit card and other assorted wallet things, it also includes a phone stand with multiple angles for your veiwing pleasure, a ruler with metric measurments, a pencil and two usb holders. If this isn't enough for you than I don't know what else I could add without making it bigger then a pocket sized peice of equipment. The whole point of this is to in some small way release some stress and weight off the back of the children and students using this. Thsi would mainly be for the younger grades of about 3rd to 5th grade. Students should be able to learn measuring skills as well as the ability to use an abacus for more basic equations. This was made to use alongside the usual school materials list.

Printer:

FLASHFORGE Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Print the case on a vertical not a horizantal. Thee best way to do it is to print on the open side of the case with supports.

Tinkercad I used Tinkercad the online progam to design this. I did fnd files off of thingiverse and made a sort of collage. I would like to thank all file and makers that uploaded these files to tinkercad for it was a great help. Thank you very much.

This the snow ski that I created to fly off the snow.  It should fit most electric RC airplanes with tricycle or tail dragger front wheels in the same 1/8 in. wire wheel struts.  The file with skig is for the front steering wheel.
After printing you will need to heat up the front part (first 1 in.) of the ski and bend up at a 30 degree angle.  
You will also need to place a spring to provide bounce and to keep the angle of the ski level during flight.  I picked up some springs at the local Home Depot and put them on each ski, with one end rapped around the axle and the other end straighten about 2 in. and place against the ski.

Notes: I print them using PLA on glass bed. Print temp: extruder 205C and heated bed at 70C. I use a 1.75mm filament and print first layer at .4mm and each layer at .2mm, with 4 solid layers top and bottom.
Bend Nose After printing, remove from printer and heat the first 1 in. of ski and bend up to a 30% angle.

Second release! V1.1.0
  • All values now save upon exit! Works upon exiting the program with any method.
  • HH:MM feature added, selectable between minutes. 2 hours 34 minutes is simply 2:34 now, rather than figuring out the full minute equivalent.
  • Hint bar added on bottom. Will show a quick hint for the field currently selected. This works for output fields as well.
  • Custom material and diameter fields added.
    • If the download does not work, it is available at our site at http://standardselectronics.com/3d-printer-calculator/ where you can also add your e-mail to the mailing list and get future update notes!

WINDOWS 10 USERS:
This has been tested to work on Windows 10, but seems that some have a bit of cosmetic edging issues. We will do some more research between versions here and correct that next release. There does not seem to be any usability issues. MAC USERS:
Porting proved problematic for specific commands within the program. An emulator (Wine/Winebottle, or Virtualbox) on the mac side may allow you to use this program. We are actively trying to find a solution and could use any help on the matter.

The Details:
Requirements are .NET 4.5 (Which it will let you download from Microsoft if it does not find it). This is a Windows only program for now, time will tell if this spreads to Apple, Android, etc. Just download and run the .msi file and your off and running!
It is a one window program, what you see is what is there. The menu system is a series of popups with extra info, handy links, and a few tips and tricks.
Let us know how it can be better! We have loaded it with data crunching abilities, and made all the fields tab friendly (check the help menu for hints). After a while, we were punching out a full set of data in seconds. We hope you enjoy it, and please, spread the word! This is freeware, and it will remain that way, share to your hearts content (just don't break it apart, modify it, and then run amok).

Upcoming Changes (No set release date):
  • Mac compatibility (very near future, will be V1.1.0 as a MacOS install file)
  • Save to file functionality (experimenting with usefulness)
  • Dual head printer options
  • Any kind of bug fixes that have been discovered by you guys (keep messaging us, or e-mail us at [email protected])

Bonus Print:
We made up a business card with 3DPEC on it. Print it out and show it off to help support us!

Infill does not matter, if you have 2 or more 'perimeters' the entire thing will be a perimeter. This is just to add something build-able to our programs page, you don't need to make this to use our program!
Visual Basic A lot of it, and a lot of math. Maybe your math teacher was right, you will use unit conversions later on in life!

comments.text: I thought I'd put this out in the open as well. You can have some of the fields as 0, including Material Upcharge. All the costs (Machine, Operator, Spool) Can also be 0 if you so choose, it will not error out. We have a 8mm/Super8 projector that requires reel adapters to use Super8 reels. Adapters can be hard to find, or hideously expensive for what they are. This is a printable adapter.
There are several different designs of adapters available, and this was based on one that I purchased to use Super8 reels with my wife's projector. I printed it in PLA and it fits on the spindle and in the reel just fine.
I used this as a way to learn Onshape better (since I already had purchased some adapters)

I got a slide projector from Craigslist that didn't have a lens cap. So I made one. I designed in Onshape and printed in Ninja Flex and it works quite nicely.

title: Replacement Bracket for Philips PowerPro vacuum (FC8760) Cleaning Wand / Hard Floor Nozzle

description.text:
The bracket on my "wheeled all-purpose nozzle" (the official name of the hard floor nozzle) used to hold the "cleaning wand" (the official name of the metal pipe) fit in place on the side of the motor unit broke, which meant having the broom stick not being neatly storable. So I designed this replacement bracket.
My vacuum model : Philips PowerPro Bagless vacuum cleaner FC8760
The part fits as it should out of the printer, with minimal effort to install. 
There is a hole suitable for an M4x12mm socket screw, for those who really want to lock the bracket in place.

comments.text: This looks interesting, as I have a similar Vacuum cleaner. Not exactly the same, but printing right now and will give feedback  :-)

description.text:
This is a sun shade I designed in OpenSCAD. It fits over the top of a full-sized iPad. Designed for use with the DJI Phantom 3 Advanced or Pro controller, but might work with other units as well.
OpenSCAD source file uploaded as well if you want to tweak it.

Designed to screw into the trim around a door frame to secure network or speaker cables.  Put a screw through the hole and add a wire tie (cable tie)-- done.  The wire tie can be replaced without unscrewing anything.  There is enough clearance and a slight upward ramp where the wire tie fits through so the tie exits upward.
When printed, the holder is about .63" wide x .78" tall.  
Sketchup file included for modifications.

I printed it sideways, so it would be easier to get off - thus why it's designed to be printed on it's side.

description.text: Fits the iPhone 6 and 6s. Simple case with apple logo and Ghost emoji.

Yesterday I got a GoPro session and thought it would be awesome to put on my shendrones tweaker 180. This is the first version of the mount I made. It should in theory work with all GoPros as they all use the same base mount. It fits the tweaker and the gopro and everything comes together well, but as of yet I haven't flown it or more importantly, crashed it.

A gyroscopic toy. Each of the shells can move independently and be rotated to create a secret little space in the middle. Each shell rotates counter to the previous one so if you put something heavy in the center it will stay upright at all times.
Suitable for printing in all filaments check out our range here:
https://www.bilby3d.com.au/DispCat.asp?CatID=19&SubCatID=107
or for those of you who love ABS:
https://www.bilby3d.com.au/DispCat.asp?CatID=19&SubCatID=88

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Either print each of the shells individually or put them all on the print bed and print at once. The files should be centered so you do not need to realign the models.

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15018. A friend of mine had posted a picture of two rings on facebook, and those rings had engines on them. He tagged his wife and asked if she'd marry him again. I knew that he wasn't going to waste his money on those rings, so I decided to print him a pair of rings. I printed them with the ring flat, the engine with the front facing down (support for the air cleaner is built in), and the accessories with the front facing up. Support is needed, obviously. When the printing is done, glue the ring to the bottom of the engine, and the accessories to the front. I used an acetone vapor bath to get a nice, glossy finish.

comments.text: That is one nice acetone bath result, I thought that you used a SLA printer at first. Really nice work. Greetings
comments.author: guaro3d

comments.text: Wow very nice! how did you get it so shiny??
comments.author: daniel541

comments.text:
I used this technique (only works with ABS): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sblh0bBHoQ
Instead of using a rice cooker, I used an aluminum loaf pan, and put it on the heated bed of my printer. I refrigerated the part before doing this, that way the acetone would condense on the part after it vaporized from the bottom of the pan. I covered the pan with aluminum foil, waited about two minutes (plenty long enough for the acetone to evaporate) and then turned off the heated bed and uncovered the pan, and let it sit to cool for about an hour. That's all there is to it.
comments.author: daniel541

The big brother to the Heavy Duty Filament Spool, it's even heavier duty. This one can hold a full kilo of filament.
The arms haven't changed, there's just more of them. The spindle has been modified slightly to take the greater weight. Print the spindle at high infill to keep it stiff - else the weight of the spool with may bend it.
The forks are wider, longer and thicker on the bottom. One side of the fork is longer to help discourage filaments from jumping off and getting wrapped around the spindle. 
The Mendel spindles are variations of thing:11447 by watsdesign.

I print the hub and arms with two extra shells for strength, infill 25%. Depending on how much your bottom layers get smooshed you may or may not need to trim around the dovetails. You should be able to get it started by hand then pound it together, or use pliers to squeeze the dovetails in place. It is supposed to be a tight fit.
Download SuperSpool.zip for all the stl files.

description.text:
My itteration of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:741041, designed by me in 123D Design from scratch. Originally inspired by the Secrid wallet. I couldn't get the shaft to print strong enough using PLA (I'm using aluminum tubing instead), that's why I left a hole in the base/lid. Shaft dimensions: 6mm x 9mm (OD x Length). Needed:
  • Exacto knife
  • Wet sandpaper (1000> grit)
  • Epoxy glue
  • 6mm rod/tubing

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50% (100% for the lever)

Notes: | Filament: Flashforge PLA | Shell thickness: 1.2mm | Bottom/top thickness: 1.2mm | Print speed: 30mm/s | Printing temp: 210C | Bed temp: 60C | Slicer: Cura (15.04.05) | Print time (total): ~8.5h |

Trim the edges of the base/lid/lever and make sure it's a flush fit between the base and the lid. You might have to wet sand down the edges of the lid and the lever a bit depending on how dimensionally correct your printer prints. There is some built in tolerances though.

description.text: This is a sleeve type case for external Sinclair ZX Spectrum Keyboard Interface developed by JROK and published here http://www.jrok.com/project/speckey/spec_key.html The case has main part and the cap which is tighten to the main part with single 2mm screw. You can add some glue to corners if the cap doesn't snap perfectly to the main part. The PCB has inside rails and FR-4 thickness should fit fine. Please note that this interface doesn't fit without a bus expansion (e.g. http://divide.cz/index.php?y=rozdvojka.en) to any newer version of ZX Spectrum (+, 128k, +2/2A/3) because of the design of PCB. CPLD socket and PS/2 connector are colliding with the case of a computer. Designed in FreeCAD v0.14

I wasn't satisfied with the existing solutions here (usually 3-4mm panel assembled) while we can do that in one piece with thin walls (2 perimeters is fine even with hundred of M8 nuts). Maybe better to print in clear PLA to make containers that are almost transparent like on my pictures :)
You can easily add some dividers if you want in sketchup.
It take ~10gr. and ~60min to print with 0.3mm layers at 40mm/s
Also, when extruded above 195Â°C the clear PLA seem to be less translucent.

title: Prusa I3 Dual, adjustable E3D printhead holder - "Slider"

description.text:
UPDATES
21.06.2016 Added also STEP and F3D (Autodesk Fusion) file formats. Welcome to use them for modifications! 09.02.2016 Figure out, my printheads are longer than the ones in drawing. So I lowered also the cooling mount for 5mm. The file is "50x50mm cooling V2- 5mm lower.stl" 27.01.2016 Added "50x50mm cooling.stl" Second version of cooling mount. I tried to implement as much as possible suggestions from ZeFrenchie (special credits) 19.01.2016 Added CoolerMount.stl - Located at back, with single 40x40 fan - need to be tested. 26.12.2015 Tested and adjusted nozzle distance, for dual color printing. Theoretical values Y=0, X=27,55mm. Actual distance: Y=2,05mm X=25,6mm. 25.12.2015 Added hotends and fans for visualization and designing of additions. 24.12.2015 Installed on my Prusa i3. Tested. So far everything works as expected. 23.12.2015 Modiefied "Holder0 Bottom V2.stl" uploaded - made rails more tight, to avoid hotend unwanted movement. INFORMATION
I decided, to upgrade my Prusa i3 to dual extruder system. I use Bowden extruders and get two E3D V6 hotend clones. Since my hotends was not the same lenght, I needed the hotend holder with possibility to adjust the hotend height.
So I go for this holder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:694135
The adjustment is possible, but I wanted easier and more precise adjustment. Then I find this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:419159
I liked the idea of adjustment with screw, but in my opinion, the nozzles was too far apart. So I decided to create my own dual printhead mount for my Prusa i3. I tried to reach following goals:
  • Lightweight
  • Nozzles - as close as possible
  • Easy and precise height adjustment respective to other nozzle
  • Mounted on standard Prusa i3 X carriage (with M4 screws)
  • Place for calibration sensor - easy to change.
    • So, there is the result - my "Slider" print head mount. It is still work in progress. The parts are still being tested, but this version must work. If you have some suggestions or want to have some modofications, please let me know!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes: Supports necessary just for some parts. For base it is necessary just for Fan pins.
Hotend E3D V6 clone from ebay Fans Two 40mm fans for cold end cooling. Proximity sensor 12mm inductive proximity sensor from ebay

title: Fence for No 71 Stanley Hand Router/Plane

description.text:
This is a fence for No 71 Stanley Hand Router/Plane.
Seems to print in PLA at 30% honeycomb infill quite well,  although you may want to add support for the screw slow.
The screw needed to attach this to the Hand Router is a 3/16" Whitworth (24 tpi) (also known as a 10-24) which can be found on ebay if your in the UK.

RepRap

Printer:

Fisher

Rafts:

No

Yes

.2mm

30% Honeycomb
Designed in Sketchup and then exported as an STL.   When testing I made smaller slicers of the part so that the print faster and I can fail fast.

title: Rostock LCD housing for smart controller

description.text:
The housing was designed for the Rostock MIni Pro. It holds a smart controller for standalone use by a SD card. Additional parts:
4 x M3 x 6 screws
4 x M3 x 10 screws
2 x M4 x 16 screws
1 x Smart controller (http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRapDiscount_Smart_Controller) Optional:
1 Knob for rotary encoder Important: I added rubber feet to my Rostock, with the included LCD mount, this offset is compensated, for use without those feet, they need to be reduced by ~4mm, otherwise there will be tension at the build plate.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Notes: No special settings required

Assembly
  • Mount the two LCD_mount pieces to the back with 4 M3 x 6 screws
  • Insert button from the back to the cover
  • Insert the smart controller to the cover
  • Mount the back to the cover and fix it with 4 M3 x 10 screws
  • Hold the housing at the desired position at the build plate and mrk the position for the holes.
  • Drill the holes with a 4mm drill
  • Mount the housing with the M4 screws to the build plate and wire it

A pair of Yoda Ears for the Star Wars fanboy/fangirl in all of us! The Head Band comes in three sizes (widths shown below): Small: 104 mm
Medium: 124 mm
Large: 144 mm Print all Ear Parts (Total of 4):
  • Left_Ear_Back.STL
  • Right_Ear_Back.STL
  • Left_Ear_Front.STL
  • Right_Ear_Front.STL
    • Choose a Head Band size:
  • Head_Band_Large.STL
  • Head_Band_Medium.STL
  • Head_Band_Small.STL
    • Print 4 x Pin.STL Please comment with your thoughts and feedback - I'd love to hear your suggestions!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Resolution:

200 Microns

Infill:

5%

Notes: All parts print without Support. Print with Raft if using a MakerBot 5th Generation Printer.

Assembly First, snap the the Left and Right Back Ears into the Head Band Ear locators. Each Front Ear half snaps into the Back half, using the two pins as secure locators. It should be a snug fit - please let me know if you find that the fit it too loose or too tight. You may need to use adhesive to hold the assembly together.

Its Christmas time and this is my project of a Christmas Tree with LEDs. The "thing" has two 3d printed parts: the tree (with LED pin holes) and the base stand.
It also requires a small circuit to power the LEDs. The circuit requires:
  • 3 x S9014 NPN Transistors
  • 3 x Electrolytic Capacitor 22uF 16V
  • 3 x 470 Ohm Resistor
  • 3 x 10K Ohm Resistor
  • 17 x Red LEDs 5mm
  • 1x Small 15x6 Holes Protoboard
    • Full details published on http://altlab.org/d/m/jpralves/newsletters/34/#Circuitos You can watch a small video on https://youtu.be/QNKqiELRP98.
